study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if medially-posted foot orthoses immediately reduce hip adduction moment and pain in females with Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome (GTPS) during walking gait.
results_summary: The study found a small pain reduction with medially-posted orthoses compared to flat inserts, but no significant changes in gait biomechanics or clinically meaningful pain reduction. No differences were detected in biomechanical or pain outcomes for the pronated-foot subgroup.
population_specificity: 53 women with Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome (GTPS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved medially-posted orthoses and flat inserts during walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of physical activity (including walking) on nocturnal rostral fluid shift, sleep patterns, and edema in hemiparetic stroke patients.
results_summary: Physical activity reduced the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) from 19 to 13 events/hour, decreased wake after sleep onset, and increased fluid volume in paretic and non-paretic arms and trunk before sleep compared to inactivity.
population_specificity: 8 hemiparetic patients post-first-ever ischemic stroke in the subacute phase (mean age 53.2 ± 16.2; 6 women).
effective_dosage: Activity included standing, calf muscle contractions, walking, and climbing stairs between 13:00 and 21:00.
study_duration: Single-day intervention with a 7-day crossover interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of testosterone treatment on various outcomes, including walking, in elderly men with low serum testosterone levels.
results_summary: Testosterone treatment slightly improved walking in elderly men with low testosterone levels, along with modest improvements in sexual function, hemoglobin, bone mineral density, vitality, and mood. However, it also increased coronary artery noncalcified plaque volume, though the clinical significance of this finding remains unclear due to study limitations.
population_specificity: Elderly men with low serum testosterone levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify walking activity parameters during supervised therapy sessions in fragility fracture patients to evaluate improvements in mobility.
results_summary: The study found that supervised therapy sessions (3-4 daily, totaling 90-120 minutes) led to significant improvements: a 30% increase in steps, 26% increase in upright time, and 49% increase in walking duration. Over 50% of daily walking activity occurred during therapy sessions.
population_specificity: Fragility fracture patients (mean age 82.5 years) undergoing rehabilitation.
study_duration: Measurements taken during the 1st and 3rd weeks of rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of educational and behavioral interventions, including walking away from crying infants, in preventing abusive head trauma (AHT) and improving parental responses to infant crying.
results_summary: The study found weak evidence that interventions increased walking away from crying infants (incidence rate ratio 1.52, 95% CI 0.94-2.45), but no significant effects on AHT prevention or other parental responses to crying.
population_specificity: Parents or caregivers of infants, particularly those at risk of abusive head trauma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cilostazol, pentoxifylline, and beraprost for improving walking distance and ankle-brachial index in patients with intermittent claudication due to lower extremity arterial occlusive disease.
results_summary: Cilostazol was most effective in increasing maximum and pain-free walking distances, followed by beraprost and pentoxifylline. Beraprost and cilostazol combined with beraprost showed the greatest improvement in ankle-brachial index, while pentoxifylline and cilostazol had fewer adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication due to lower extremity arterial occlusive disease (total 5,352 patients across 29 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Qili Qiangxin Capsule with cardiac exercise rehabilitation improves cardiac and motor function in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in total effective rate, 6-minute walking distance, BNP levels, and left ventricular end-diastolic diameter compared to the control group, with no significant changes in other measured indicators.
population_specificity: 93 CHF patients admitted to Shanghai's Putuo District Central Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exoskeleton-assisted walking improves gait parameters in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that robotic exoskeletons improved gait, including reduced metabolic cost of walking, increased walking speed, and enhanced knee and hip extension during stance. Ankle-actuated exoskeletons also promoted normal ankle rocker function.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare estimated walking speed using the Walking Speed Questionnaire (WSQ) with recorded walking speed and examine the effects of different start conditions and instructions in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The WSQ provided a reasonably accurate estimate of walking speed at usual pace, though it generally underestimated speed compared to recorded conditions. Adjusting the WSQ cutoff to 1.17 m/s improved sensitivity while maintaining high specificity (94%) and accuracy (82%).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 60 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine sex-stratified differences in heart failure symptom changes, including walking problems, among hospitalized individuals with different heart failure subtypes.
results_summary: The study found that walking problems were more prevalent in women with heart failure, particularly those with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), and symptom worsening was associated with specific clinical factors like coronary artery disease and hypertension.
population_specificity: 528 hospitalized individuals (302 men, 226 women) diagnosed with heart failure (HFrEF, HFmrEF, or HFpEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of bobble-head doll syndrome in a young child and evaluate the effectiveness of endoscopic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that head bobbing in the patient increased with walking, emotions, and stress but disappeared completely after endoscopic cystoventriculostomy and cystocisternostomy. The patient showed normal growth during the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 1.5-year-old Asian-Syrian girl with bobble-head doll syndrome and suprasellar arachnoid cyst.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether low-frequency pulsed electromagnetic field (PEMF) therapy could improve walking performance, fatigue, depression symptoms, and quality of life in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between PEMF therapy and placebo in improving fatigue, walking function, depression symptoms, or quality of life in RRMS patients at post-intervention or follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and minimal to significant disability.
effective_dosage: PEMF therapy initially at 15Hz, gradually increased to 30Hz (intensity between 25-35µT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-to-moderate intensity aerobic training (via cycling) on cardiorespiratory functions and functional capacity in chronic unconditioned stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that submaximal parameters (VO2-VT and OUES) improved significantly in the intervention group, though peak oxygen uptake (VO2 peak) did not. Functional Independence Measure improved in both groups, but 6-Minute Walking Test (6MWT) improved only in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Chronic unconditioned stroke patients
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of aerobic training by bicycle (low-to-moderate intensity), 5 days per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the scope of clinical evidence covered by systematic reviews involving digital biomarkers, including outcomes related to walking.
results_summary: Walking was one of the most commonly reported outcomes (12/31, 39%) in the systematic reviews, indicating its significance in digital biomarker research. The study highlighted the use of various digital devices like smart shoes and socks to measure gait patterns and other walking-related functions.
population_specificity: Patients with circulatory and respiratory system diseases, among other conditions.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of dexamethasone combined with tranexamic acid in the perioperative period of total hip arthroplasty, particularly focusing on inflammation, pain, and recovery metrics.
results_summary: The combination of TXA and DEXA significantly reduced postoperative inflammation (CRP, IL-6), walking and rest pain scores, nausea, fatigue, analgesic use, and hospital stay compared to TXA alone, with no significant differences in blood loss or complications.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (100 cases, divided into two groups of 50 each).
effective_dosage: TXA (15 mg/kg before skin incision and 3 hours later); DEXA (20 mg intravenously after anesthesia onset and again 24 hours later).
study_duration: Perioperative period (intervention administered during and up to 24 hours post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in exercise therapy recommendations, including Walking, for hemodialysis (HD) patients and identify barriers to its implementation.
results_summary: The study found that low/moderate-intensity exercise, including Walking, for at least thirty minutes five times per week is advisable for HD patients, with benefits demonstrated in the included articles. Barriers to exercise were also identified, including patient restrictions and environmental problems.
population_specificity: End-stage kidney disease (ESKD) patients undergoing hemodialysis (HD).
effective_dosage: At least thirty minutes five times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the biomechanics of walking and other functional outcomes in patients with COPD to understand movement patterns and stability.
results_summary: Patients with COPD exhibited altered gait patterns (shorter, wider steps, reduced speed) and increased postural sway, suggesting compensatory mechanisms for stability. Muscle mechanics in COPD remain understudied, but respiratory dyssynchrony is well-documented.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the decline in physical function with age in dogs and assess the potential utility of human-developed clinical tools and interventions for mitigating this decline.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the parallels between human and canine aging, highlighting the potential for adapting human clinical assessments and interventions to improve physical function in geriatric dogs, but does not provide specific results regarding walking.
population_specificity: Geriatric dogs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an 8-week aerobic cycling intervention could improve locomotor function, specifically gait velocity and biomechanics, in individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The abstract is incomplete, but the study appears to investigate improvements in gait velocity and biomechanics following aerobic cycling in PD patients. Full results are not provided.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate idiopathic Parkinson's disease (N = 28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of nonconventional exercise interventions, including walking, on functional capacity and quality of life in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: Walking was the most frequent exercise studied, with 13 out of 14 studies showing significantly improved functional capacity and 10 showing significantly improved quality of life in heart failure patients.
population_specificity: Adults with heart failure (879 patients across 14 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank the effectiveness of different types of exercise, including walking-related interventions like body weight support treadmill training (BWS_TT) and robotic assisted gait training (RA_GT), for improving symptoms in Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: BWS_TT showed the best improvement in balance, gait velocity, and walking distance, while RA_GT was most effective for reducing freezing of gait. The study found low-quality evidence supporting the effectiveness of these walking-related interventions for adults with Parkinson's disease.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50 years or older with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to present diagnostic approaches and relevant diagnoses for common pediatric cases, including refusal to walk, during night and weekend radiology shifts.
results_summary: The study highlighted that refusal to walk in children is a nonspecific sign of acute musculoskeletal disease, with clinical examination being essential to narrow down potential causes, such as coxitis fugax or serious conditions like septic arthritis/osteomyelitis.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents presenting with acute symptoms (e.g., refusal to walk) during night and weekend radiology shifts.

study_goal: To determine if exoskeleton-assisted walking (EAW) improves pulmonary ventilation, motor function, and daily activities as effectively as conventional exercise in people with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: EAW improved forced vital capacity, predicted FVC%, forced expiratory volume, basic activities of daily living, and distal femoral cartilage more than conventional exercise. No differences were found in trunk/lower extremity motor function, bone mineral density, or adverse events.
population_specificity: 40 participants (7 females, 33 males; age 37.1±12.0 years) with thoracic SCI.

study_goal: To investigate the clinical efficacy of an integrated multidomain intervention, including physical exercise, on cognitive function and quality of life in older adults with multimorbidity and physio-cognitive decline syndrome (PCDS).
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved global cognitive performance, specific cognitive domains (concentration, language, abstract thinking, orientation), reduced frailty scores, and enhanced quality of life in older adults with PCDS.
population_specificity: Community-living older adults with multimorbidity and physio-cognitive decline syndrome (PCDS), specifically those with Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) scores ≥18.
effective_dosage: Sixteen 2-hour sessions per year, including physical exercise components.

study_goal: To compare the clinical effectiveness of sodium polynucleotide, classic hyaluronic acid, and crosslinked hyaluronic acid for managing painful knee osteoarthritis, particularly in relation to walking and other activities.
results_summary: Polynucleotide showed a higher and faster reduction in pain scores during weight-bearing, walking, and rest compared to classic and crosslinked hyaluronic acid. All groups improved functional disability and quality of life without severe adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic painful knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Intra-articular injections administered three times at one-week intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether testosterone treatment improves self-reported walking ability in older men with late-onset hypogonadism.
results_summary: Testosterone treatment improved self-reported walking ability in men with late-onset hypogonadism, along with sexual function, mood, and depressive symptoms. No improvement was observed in men without unequivocal hypogonadism.
population_specificity: Older men with late-onset hypogonadism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding kicking techniques to boxing training improves balance and adherence in people with Parkinson's disease compared to boxing alone.
results_summary: Both boxing with kicking and boxing alone improved balance in participants, but no significant difference was found between the two groups. The interventions were feasible, safe, and well-accepted by participants.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease (median age 64 years; median disease duration 5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the patency of the Eluvia drug-eluting stent (DES) versus bare metal stents (BMS) for treating femoropopliteal artery lesions in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found that the Eluvia DES had significantly higher 12-month primary patency (83.2%) compared to BMS (74.3%). Health-related quality of life and walking function were assessed, but specific results for walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (Rutherford category 2, 3, or 4) of the native superficial femoral artery or proximal popliteal artery with stenosis ≥70%, vessel diameter of 4 to 6 mm, and total lesion length of 30 to 210 mm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ballistic resistance training is more effective than non-ballistic exercise rehabilitation for improving mobility, strength, and balance in people recovering from traumatic brain injury, and whether improved mobility enhances health-related quality of life.
results_summary: Ballistic resistance training showed a modest but statistically significant improvement in mobility (3 points higher on the HiMAT scale) compared to non-ballistic training, with greater benefits for those with severe mobility limitations. Secondary outcomes (walking speed, strength, balance, quality of life) showed similar effects between groups by 6 months.
population_specificity: 144 people with neurological movement disorders affecting mobility due to traumatic brain injury.
study_duration: 3 months of intervention, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the most effective type, duration, and frequency of forest therapies, including walking, for improving physiological and psychological health in elderly populations.
results_summary: Forest walking, alone or combined with other activities, was found to be the most effective intervention, improving physical health (e.g., reduced blood pressure and heart rate) and psychological well-being (e.g., reduced depression and stress). However, the lack of high-quality studies limits the strength of these findings.
population_specificity: Healthy and pathological elderly populations (>60 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antinociceptive efficacy, residual motor block, and time for postoperative functional recovery of the preoperative PENG block in patients with hip fracture.
results_summary: The PENG block provided effective analgesia, reducing pain by at least 3 points on the VNS at all evaluation points, with an average difference of 7.5 points. It facilitated safe patient transfer and placement without complications and promoted early mobility and rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty for hip fracture.
study_duration: Evaluated before the blockade, 30 minutes later, in the immediate postoperative period, and 24 hours after the intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether functional electrical stimulation treatment improves gait parameters (e.g., walking speed and step length) in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that functional electrical stimulation increased walking speed and step length in children with cerebral palsy, suggesting it may improve their walking ability. However, the study noted limitations in blinding methods and called for more research to support these findings.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (282 participants, 142 in the treatment group and 140 in control groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a 6-month walking program on biochemical parameters in patients with type-2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study measured changes in various biochemical markers (e.g., plasma glucose, lipids, liver enzymes, and inflammatory markers) before and after the walking intervention, using statistical tests to assess differences. The abstract does not specify the direction or magnitude of these changes.
population_specificity: 40 sedentary patients with type-2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the association between backward walking and cognition in persons with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: One study found lower backward walking speed in Parkinson's patients with poorer attention test performances, while another showed a weak correlation between executive cognitive functions and backward walking speed. The review highlights inconsistent results and the need for further investigation.
population_specificity: Persons with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if robot-assisted balance treatment combined with conventional physical therapy improves static and dynamic balance, gait, fatigue, and cognitive performance more effectively than conventional therapy alone in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that robotic training with physical therapy would enhance balance, gait, and cognitive outcomes compared to conventional therapy, potentially reducing disability and improving quality of life in stroke patients.
population_specificity: Stroke patients of both sexes, treated at a rehabilitation center in Rome.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes per session, 3 times a week for 4 weeks (12 total sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining spinal cord stimulation with activity-based training for improving sensorimotor and autonomic functions in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that spinal cord stimulation combined with activity-based training improved walking, voluntary muscle activation, and autonomic functions (e.g., lower urinary tract, bowel, metabolic, and thermoregulatory functions) compared to activity-based training alone. However, evidence for combined approaches is limited, and optimal protocols remain uncertain.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (79 participants across 15 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of herbal activated carbon smokeless moxibustion and traditional moxibustion in treating knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the efficacy or safety of the interventions, as it describes the study design and outcomes to be measured.
population_specificity: Subjects with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren Lawrence grade II or III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robot-assisted rehabilitation (RAR) versus conventional rehabilitation (CR) on physical function and pain in patients who underwent total knee or hip replacements.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) training significantly improved pain and walking speed compared to CR in total knee replacement patients, though with high heterogeneity in walking speed results. The study suggests RAR may be effective but calls for more high-quality research to confirm long-term benefits.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee or hip replacements.
effective_dosage: HAL training for 5 days (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if overground gait training delivered through an active video game could improve walking capacity and anaerobic performance in children with cerebral palsy post-surgery.
results_summary: The study compared gait training using an active video game versus treadmill training, measuring walking capacity (6-Min Walk Test), anaerobic performance (Muscle Power Sprint Test), and physical fitness (Shuttle Run Test). Satisfaction was assessed via the Physical Activity Enjoyment Scale, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 10-18 years with cerebral palsy, at least 7 weeks post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on design interventions that influence exiting attempts in dementia care units, focusing on architectural and clinical practices.
results_summary: The study identified five interior design interventions at egress doorways (e.g., floor grid patterns, mirrors, murals) that may reduce exiting attempts in dementia patients. It highlighted the lack of recent empirical studies and the need for further research on design interventions in dementia care.
population_specificity: Individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementias in secured dementia care units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary weight loss combined with aerobic exercise and/or reduced sitting on walking self-efficacy and satisfaction with physical functioning in older adults.
results_summary: All groups showed improved walking self-efficacy at 6 months, with greater improvements in groups involving aerobic exercise. Only the reduced sitting group maintained improved walking self-efficacy at 18 months. All groups reported increased satisfaction with physical functioning at both time points, and weight change was negatively associated with improvements in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (N=112, mean age 70.21 ± 4.43 years)
study_duration: 6-month intervention followed by a 12-month maintenance period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an 8-week aerobic walking program in improving sexual dysfunction in females with systemic autoimmune rheumatic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that an 8-week aerobic walking program was successful in improving female sexual dysfunction, though the majority of studies included were of low methodological quality.
population_specificity: Females with systemic autoimmune rheumatic disorders (systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic sclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a multilevel, faith-based intervention linking churches to local parks on Latino adults' moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and health-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study proposes a scalable model for increasing PA through park-based exercise classes, walking groups, and church events, but final efficacy results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Latino adult parishioners (n=1204) from Catholic churches (n=14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if interrupting prolonged sitting with short bouts of walking over multiple days improves glucose metabolism in children compared to uninterrupted sitting.
results_summary: Daily interrupted sitting resulted in 21% lower insulin and 10% lower C-peptide area under the curve, along with improved Matsuda and Glucose Effectiveness Indices, but no differences in energy intake or expenditure.
population_specificity: Healthy, normoglycemic children aged 7-11 years (N=93).
effective_dosage: 3 minutes of moderate-intensity walking every 30 minutes for 3 hours daily.

study_goal: To compare the effects of core stabilization (CS) and dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) on balance, trunk function, mobility, falling, and spasticity in people with multiple sclerosis (PWMS).
results_summary: The DNS group showed significant improvements in balance, trunk function, postural stability, falling rate, mobility, and spasticity compared to the CS group. Both groups improved in most outcome measures after 5 weeks of intervention, except for the modified Ashworth scale.
population_specificity: 64 people with multiple sclerosis (PWMS), aged 30-50, with an expanded disability status scale between 2 and 5.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of 60 minutes each, 3 times a week for 5 weeks.
study_duration: 5 weeks of intervention with a 17-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity endurance treadmill exercise could slow the progression of Parkinson's disease (PD) compared to moderate-intensity exercise.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess the efficacy of high-intensity treadmill exercise on PD progression using the MDS-UPDRS motor score, with secondary outcomes including dopamine transporter binding, physical fitness, and quality of life. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Persons diagnosed with PD within 3 years and untreated with symptomatic therapy at baseline.
effective_dosage: Moderate intensity (4 days/week, 30 min/session at 60-65% max heart rate) and high intensity (4 days/week, 30 min/session at 80-85% max heart rate).
study_duration: 18 months of intervention, with follow-up for 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pooled effectiveness and feasibility of telerehabilitation, including walking-based interventions, in improving functional capacity and exercise perception among patients with COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that telerehabilitation, including walking tests, significantly improved functional capacity (6-minute walking test, 30-second sit-to-stand test) and reduced dyspnoea in COVID-19 patients, with an 88.46% completion rate and minimal adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19 (334 participants across four studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hypertension management, including antihypertensive drugs, influences the occurrence or progression of frailty in older adults, with walking speed as one of the frailty indicators.
results_summary: The study found an indirect relationship between higher AT11RaAb levels and decreased walking speed, indicating potential frailty risk. No significant differences in frailty status were observed between hypertensive intervention and control groups after 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65 and over.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a preoperative walking intervention enhanced with goal setting and telephonic coaching could improve postoperative recovery in frail older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in postoperative recovery scores between the intervention and control groups, despite intervention patients increasing their average daily step counts. The walking intervention did not lead to improved recovery outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: Frail older adults aged 60+ scheduled for surgery within 3-8 weeks, scoring 4+ on the Edmonton Frail Scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether telmisartan improves 6-minute walk distance compared with placebo in patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Telmisartan did not significantly improve 6-minute walk distance or any secondary outcomes compared with placebo. The adjusted between-group difference in walk distance was -16.8 m (95% CI, -35.9 m to 2.2 m; P = .08).
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity PAD (mean age 67.3 years; 40.4% women; 71.1% Black individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week tele-exercise training program, including walking, improved cardiorespiratory fitness and heart rate recovery in patients with cardiometabolic multimorbidity.
results_summary: The study found that the tele-exercise training program significantly increased vigorous-intensity physical activity, walking behavior, and total physical activity, leading to elevated cardiorespiratory fitness and improved heart rate recovery.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiometabolic multimorbidity (n=83, with 68 completers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a theory-driven Nordic walking intervention using a socio-ecological approach for type 2 diabetes patients in Spain, and to explore its feasibility and healthcare professionals' opinions on its applicability.
results_summary: The study suggests that integrating a socio-ecological approach into primary care visits could reduce physical activity drop-out ratios and increase activity levels in type 2 diabetes patients compared to general walking advice or Nordic walking alone. Qualitative analysis will explore reasons for the interventions' effectiveness.
population_specificity: Physically inactive patients with type 2 diabetes, older than 40 years, and without health contraindications to physical activity.
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week for twelve weeks.
study_duration: Twelve weeks, with follow-ups at 9 and 21 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between gadolinium-based contrast agent (GBCA) exposures and self-reported disability or performance measures in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The study found no detrimental effects of GBCA exposure on self-reported disability or physical/cognitive performance measures. Some weak associations suggested potential benefits with greater GBCA exposures, but these were not consistent after covariate adjustment.
population_specificity: 1059 MS patients with a mean age of 44.0 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical value of PB-MNCs therapy in improving tissue perfusion, ulcer healing, and walking capability in no-option CLTI diabetic patients.
results_summary: PB-MNCs therapy led to improved tissue perfusion, a high rate of ulcer healing, and restored walking capability, with a 16% amputation rate at 1 year.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) deemed ineligible for revascularization.
effective_dosage: Multiple cell treatments repeated up to three times (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up period of 1 year after the first treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cardiometabolic health effects of replacing sitting with light-intensity physical activity (LIPA) and vigorous-intensity exercise (EX) in persons with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Replacing sitting with LIPA (including light-intensity walking) improved cardiometabolic health similarly to vigorous-intensity exercise, with less perceived exertion. Both interventions showed benefits compared to prolonged sitting.
population_specificity: Mildly disabled persons with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS).
effective_dosage: LIPA: 2.7 hours of light-intensity walking/day; EX: 1.3 hours of vigorous-intensity cycling/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 12-month effects of physical therapist-led care versus arthroscopy on trunk, pelvis, and hip kinematics during walking in individuals with femoroacetabular impingement syndrome.
results_summary: The personalized hip therapy group showed increased peak hip adduction moments during walking compared to the arthroscopy group, which remained unchanged. No biomechanical changes favoring arthroscopy were detected, suggesting personalized hip therapy may elicit greater improvements in hip moments during walking.
population_specificity: Individuals with femoroacetabular impingement syndrome (mean age ~35-36; ~41-48% female).

study_goal: To test the feasibility of a walking programme for community-dwelling adults recovering from hip fracture.
results_summary: The walking programme was acceptable, could be implemented as intended, and demonstrated preliminary evidence of efficacy in increasing physical activity, but low demand (24% recruitment rate) threatened feasibility.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged at least 60 years recovering from hip fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an app-based interval walking training (IWT) program could increase moderate-and-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) over 52 weeks compared to standard care in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found no significant increase in MVPA time with the app-based IWT compared to standard care, but it did observe improvements in physical health-related quality of life and a marginal reduction in waist circumference in the IWT group. No differences were noted in other secondary outcomes like physical fitness or weight.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes referred to municipality-based lifestyle programs (mean age 59.6 years, 59.8% male).
effective_dosage: 3 times per week for 30-60 minutes of interval walking training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of a walking-focused proactive counseling intervention for Black Veterans with chronic musculoskeletal pain, particularly comparing those with and without mental health disorders.
results_summary: The intervention improved global perceptions of pain and pain intensity/interference at 3 months for Veterans with mental health disorders, while those without such disorders showed improvement in pain-related disability at 6 months. However, mental health disorder patients did not experience reductions in pain-related disability, suggesting a need for more intensive treatment.
population_specificity: Black Veterans with chronic musculoskeletal pain, with or without mental health disorders (depressive disorder, anxiety disorder, substance use disorder, PTSD, or serious mental illness).
effective_dosage: 6 telephone coaching sessions over 8-14 weeks to encourage walking.
study_duration: 8-14 weeks (intervention), with follow-up at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: To determine if motion control walking shoes are superior to neutral walking shoes in reducing knee pain on walking in people with lateral knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that motion control shoes were superior to neutral shoes for reducing knee pain or improving secondary outcomes. Adverse events were minor and similar between groups.
population_specificity: People with symptomatic radiographic lateral tibiofemoral osteoarthritis from the community and a volunteer database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physical effects, safety, and feasibility of prehabilitation (including walking) in orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT) candidates with end-stage liver disease.
results_summary: Prehabilitation improved aerobic capacity (VO2 peak), 6-minute walking distance, hand grip strength, liver frailty index, and quality of life. Feasibility was high in supervised programs (>94% adherence), with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Adult OLT candidates with end-stage liver disease (MELD score ≥12 or Child-Pugh classification B/C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate goal-setting and achievement for Botulinum toxin injection (BTI) in managing spasticity-related walking impairments in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: Goals related to walking and mobility (e.g., stability, walking distance) were frequently achieved (85.77%), showing BTI's effectiveness for gait improvement in MS-related spasticity. Lower limb goals (89.1% of cases) had higher success rates than upper limb goals.
population_specificity: Spastic patients with mild-to-moderate multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the clinical characteristics and outcomes of traumatic cervical spine injuries in older adults, particularly focusing on injuries caused by ground-level falls.
results_summary: The study found that older adults who sustained cervical spine injuries from ground-level falls had poorer pre-injury health conditions and worse outcomes (9% mortality, 67% walking independence, 80% home-discharge rates at 6 months). Preexisting medical comorbidities and frailty were associated with unfavorable outcomes, independent of age or neurological impairment severity.
population_specificity: Patients aged 65 years or older with traumatic cervical spine injuries in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and effects of a four-week Nordic walking exercise program against climbing and social contact groups in patients with anxiety disorders or PTSD.
results_summary: Nordic walking significantly reduced symptoms of anxiety disorders and PTSD, showing comparable benefits to climbing and social contact groups, but without additional clinically relevant advantages.
population_specificity: Outpatients aged 18-65 with anxiety disorders or PTSD (ICD-10 F 40, F 41, F 43.1), mostly female (75%), treatment-resistant (95%), and averaging 3.8 psychiatric comorbidities.
effective_dosage: Eight sessions of 90 minutes each over four weeks.
study_duration: Four weeks, with follow-ups at three and six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of introducing a structured, progressive walking protocol (Walk 'n Watch) on walking endurance and quality of life in adult stroke patients during inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that the Walk 'n Watch protocol improved walking endurance (measured by the 6-Minute Walk Test) and quality-of-life measures compared to usual care, with progressive intensity guided by heart rate and step counters.
population_specificity: Medically stable adults post-stroke who could take five steps with maximum assistance from one therapist.
effective_dosage: Minimum of 30 minutes of weight-bearing, walking-related activities, progressively increased in intensity.
study_duration: 4 weeks (primary outcome), with additional follow-up at 12 months post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of a 12-week treatment with acipimox on skeletal muscle ATP content in patients with mitochondrial disease and myopathy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of acipimox on walking or ATP content, as the study is described as ongoing or not yet completed.
population_specificity: Patients with mitochondrial disease and myopathy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (acipimox or placebo, with low-dose aspirin as a non-investigational product).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a therapeutic program combining muscle resistance, balance, and gait exercises with and without minimalist shoes on clinical, functional, and biomechanical outcomes in older women with medial knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that gait intervention programs with minimalist shoes improved pain, functionality, and reduced knee joint overload in older women with knee osteoarthritis, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract. Secondary outcomes included improvements in walking tests and balance metrics.
population_specificity: Older women with medial knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for two months, totaling 16 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of respirator intervention on cardiopulmonary indicators during walking in high-PM environments.
results_summary: The study found that respirator intervention was occasionally associated with reduced systolic blood pressure and increased heart rate variability, but effects were inconsistent across cities and parameters.
population_specificity: 128 healthy university students in four Chinese cities.
study_duration: 2-hour walking intervention followed by 5-hour indoor observation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a patient with sirenomelia could achieve walking ability after surgical separation of the legs and rehabilitation.
results_summary: The patient successfully began ambulating on stumps post-surgery and later walked with prostheses, demonstrating that walking is achievable in selected sirenomelia cases with appropriate surgical and therapeutic intervention.
population_specificity: A single patient with sirenomelia (legs fused at birth, feet facing backward) and no other life-threatening anomalies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an unsupervised 12-week online yoga program compared to online education for improving knee pain during walking and physical function in adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that the online yoga program improved physical function but not knee pain during walking at 12 weeks, with benefits not sustained at 24 weeks. More yoga participants achieved the minimal clinically important difference for both outcomes compared to controls.
population_specificity: 212 adults with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 1 video per week, with each session to be performed 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trunk stabilization exercises using laser pointer visual feedback improve balance, walking, and fall efficacy in patients with chronic stroke compared to traditional exercises without visual feedback.
results_summary: Both groups improved in balance, plantar pressure, walking speed, and fall efficacy, but the experimental group (with visual feedback) showed significantly greater improvements in Berg Balance Scale scores, dynamic plantar pressure, 10-m walk test, and Fall Efficacy Scale scores.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic stroke
